acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: In the late 1980s, Daniel Kazimierski donated to the Tamiment Library a group of photographic portraits of veterans from the Abraham Lincoln Brigade he shot and then assembled as a mock-up to promote an idea for a book on this subject (the project was never completed). In 2013, Mr. Kazimierski donated the remainder of materials that he assembled for this project and a related project (a short documentary film on the same subject).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The materials in this collection were created by photographer Daniel Kazimierski for four related and sometimes overlapping projects about veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade.

Still images, including black and white negatives and photographic prints, shot beginning in 1983 and blah were shot for a book project and assembled by him in a mockup for the book used to promote the idea to publishers (it was never published) and also reproduced for an exhibit that was displayed/mounted at ____. Both projects were titled, "For Whom The Bell Tolled." He also recorded interviews with many of his subjectst on audiocassette tapes. Then in blah he began work on and shot film and recorded reel to reel interviews with its subjects Stanley Postek and Randall "Pete" Smith.

The collection is composed of still and moving images of, and audiotapes of interviews with, veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade living in the New York area in the the early to mid-1980s. Still images include negatives and photographs shot and printed between 1983 and 1984, and an exhibit mounted in the late 1980s; moving images include "Comrades," a 12-minute color and sound documentary film produced in 1987 about veterans Stanley Postek and Randall "Pete" Smith, and video copies of the film.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Series contains a binder with 43 pages of black and white negatives, each containing 12 portraits (twelve 6 x 6 centimeter negatives) of the New York-area veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade, accompanied by 43 matching contact proofs; thirty 11 inch x 14 inch silver gelatin prints from the negatives; a mockup for a proposed book and an exhibit (mounted on 10 inch x 16 inch panels ) that include portraits printed from the negatives. Mockup and exhibit have similar but not completely identical contents--both have the same title ("For Whom the Bell Tolled"), title page/panel, introduction and introductory quotations, and have the same accompanying quotations for their images, but the mockup includes 26 portraits, while the exhibit has 27, and exhibit includes the addition of portraits of Morris Brier and James Yates, but is missing the portrait of Leonora Temple that is present in the mockup. All materials but the exhibit were shot and printed between 1983 and 1984; the exhibit was printed in the later 1980s. Quotations from the veterans that accompany the photographs were drawn from interviews conducted and recorded by Kazimierski.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Materials include "Comrades," a 16 mm twelve-minute documentary film that contains interviews with New York metropolitan area Abraham Lincoln Brigade veterans Stanley Postek and Randall "Pete" Smith. The film is color synch sound an optical track and is on one ree; it was shot between 1984 and 1986 and completed in 1987. Materials also include a U-matic videocassette film-to-tape transfer from the film, and a DVD reference screening copy transferred from the U-matic videocassette.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Five audiocassette tapes (three 120-minute and two 90-minute) with interviews recorded between 1983 and 1984 with the following 22 Abraham Lincoln Brigade veterans: Charles Nusser, Louis Lefkowitz, Abe Smorodin, Moe Fishman, Lester Gittelson, Ken Graeber, Hy Wallach, Steven Zak, Irving Weissman, Bill Van Felix, Joe Whelan, Stanley Postek, Edward "Frenchy" Robinson, Matti Mattson, Albert Koslow, Ken (Leonard) Lamb, Lawrence O'Toole, Joe Brandt, Morris Brier, Court Bevensee, J. Loftin, and Barney Brostoff. These were recorded as part of Kazimierski's' still photographs project. Five reel-to-reel 1/4" audiotapes containing interviews with Stanley Postek and Randall "Pete" Smith interviews with recorded between 1985 and 1986 for the documentary film, "Comrades."
